explanation_txt:
The atomic weight of sulphur =32

In \(SCl_{2} \) valency of sulphur =2

So equivalent mass of sulphur \(=\cfrac{32}{2} =16\) .

quest_title: Compounds obtained by heating iodo ethane with KCN when completely hydrolysised gives out ______.
explanation_txt:
When iodo ethane is warmed with an inorganic cyanide like potassium cyanide, ethyl cyanide is formed with is important because cyanide increase the number of carbon atoms in the molecule. When ethyl eyanide is further hydrolyze in acidic medium carboxylic acid is formed.

\(CH_3CH_2I+KCN \xrightarrow[-KI]{}CH_3CH_2CN\xrightarrow[]{H_2O/H^+}\underset{Propanoic\, acid}{CH_3CH_2COOH}\)

quest_title: Angular momentum is
explanation_txt:
In physics, a polar vector is a vector such as the radius vector \(\vec{r}\) that reverses sign when the coordinate axes are reversed. Polar vectors are the type of vector usually simply known as vectors. Examples of polar vectors include \(\vec{r}\), the velocity vector \(\vec{v}\), momentum \(\vec{P}\), and force \(\vec{F}\).

In contrast, pseudovectors (also called axial vectors) do not reverse sign when the coordinate axes are reversed. The cross product of two polar vectors is a pseudovector. For example, Angular Momentum \(\vec{L}=\vec{r}\times \vec{P}\).
question_plain_title: Angular momentum is
explanation_plain_text:
In physics, a polar vector is a vector such as the radius vector that reverses sign when the coordinate axes are reversed. Polar vectors are the type of vector usually simply known as vectors. Examples of polar vectors include , the velocity vector , momentum , and force .

In contrast, pseudovectors (also called axial vectors) do not reverse sign when the coordinate axes are reversed. The cross product of two polar vectors is a pseudovector. For example, Angular Momentum .

quest_title: If a car at rest accelerates uniformly to a speed of 144 km/h in 20 s. Then it covers a distance of
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Here } v = 144 k m / h = 40 m / s } \\ { v = u + a t \Rightarrow 40 = 0 + 20 \times a \Rightarrow a = 2 m / s ^ { 2 } } \\ { \therefore s = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } a t ^ { 2 } = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \times 2 \times ( 20 ) ^ { 2 } = 400 m } \end{array}\)

quest_title: A uniform circular disc of mass M and radius R rolls on a smooth horizontal surface without slipping with a linear velocity v then KE is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{KE}=\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{rot}}+\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{tra}}\)

\(\qquad =1 / 2 \mathrm{I} \omega^{2}+1 / 2 \mathrm{mv}^{2}\)

\(\qquad =\cfrac{1}{2}\times \cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{mR}^{2} \cfrac{v^{2}}{R^{2}}+\cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)

\(\qquad = \cfrac{3}{4} mv^2\)

quest_title: The frequency of a weightless spring is n for a mass m. This spring is cut in two half and mass 2m is attached to one part then frequency of oscillation will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{n}=\cfrac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\cfrac{k}{m}}\)

If spring cut in two halves, \(k' = 2k\)

\(\mathrm{n}^{\prime}=\cfrac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\cfrac{2 k}{2 m}}=\mathrm{n}\)

explanation_txt:

\(W=JQ\) where ‘J’ is a conversion factor having value 4.2 Joule/calorie.

quest_title: 0.93 watt-hour of energy is supplied to a block of ice weighing 10 gm. It is found that
ans2_txt: The entire block melts and the water attains a temperature of 4°C
explanation_txt:
Energy supplied \(= 0.93 \times 3600\) joules \(= 3348\) joules

Heat required to melt 10 gms of ice \(= 10 \times 80 \times 4.18 = 3344\) joules

Hence block of ice just melts.
question_plain_title: 0.93 watt-hour of energy is supplied to a block of ice weighing 10 gm. It is found that
explanation_plain_text:
Energy supplied joules joules

Heat required to melt 10 gms of ice joules

Hence block of ice just melts.
ans2_plain_text: The entire block melts and the water attains a temperature of 4°C

quest_title: The saturation vapour pressure of water at 100°C is
explanation_txt: At boiling point, saturation vapour pressure becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. Therefore, at 100°C for water. S.V.P. = 760 mm of Hg (atm pressure).
question_plain_title: The saturation vapour pressure of water at 100°C is
explanation_plain_text: At boiling point, saturation vapour pressure becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. Therefore, at 100°C for water. S.V.P. = 760 mm of Hg (atm pressure).

quest_title: A concave and convex lens have the same focal length of 20 cm and are put into contact to form a lens combination. The combination is used to view an object of 5 \(\textit{cm}\) length kept at 20 cm from the lens combination. As compared to the object, the image will be
ans3_txt: Of the same size as the object and erect
ans4_txt: Of the same size as the object but inverted
explanation_txt:
Resultant focal length \(\cfrac{1}{F}=\cfrac{1}{f_{1}}+\cfrac{1}{f_{2}}=\cfrac{1}{0.2}+\cfrac{1}{-0.2}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow F=\infty \)

\(\therefore \) It behaves as a plane slab of glass. Therefore, the image formed will be of same size and erect.
question_plain_title: A concave and convex lens have the same focal length of 20 cm and are put into contact to form a lens combination. The combination is used to view an object of 5 length kept at 20 cm from the lens combination. As compared to the object, the image will be
explanation_plain_text:
Resultant focal length

It behaves as a plane slab of glass. Therefore, the image formed will be of same size and erect.
ans3_plain_text: Of the same size as the object and erect
ans4_plain_text: Of the same size as the object but inverted

\(=\cfrac{1.22 \times 4000 \times 10^{-10}}{5} \times \cfrac{180^{\circ}}{\pi} \times 60 \times 60\)
\(=0.02^{\prime \prime}\)

quest_title: In a Young's double slit experiment, the central point on the screen is
explanation_txt:
In the normal adjustment of Young’s double slit experiment, path difference between the waves at central location is always zero.

So, maxima is obtained at central position.

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: A parallel monochromatic beam of light is incident normally on a narrow slit. A diffraction pattern is formed on a screen placed perpendicular to the direction of incident beam. At the first maximum of the diffraction pattern the phase difference between the rays coming from the edges of the slit is
explanation_txt:
Path difference between the wavelets from the top edge and the bottom edge of the slit is \(\Delta x =d\sin\theta\) where \(d\) is the slit width.

Phase difference \(\phi = \cfrac { 2 \pi } { \lambda } ( \Delta x ) = \cfrac { 2 \pi } { \lambda } ( d \sin \theta )\)

The first minima of the diffraction pattern occurs when \(d \sin \theta = \lambda\) i.e. \(\sin\theta=\cfrac{\lambda}{d}\).

\(\phi = \cfrac { 2 \pi } { \lambda } \left( d \times \cfrac { \lambda } { d } \right) = 2 \pi\)
question_plain_title: A parallel monochromatic beam of light is incident normally on a narrow slit. A diffraction pattern is formed on a screen placed perpendicular to the direction of incident beam. At the first maximum of the diffraction pattern the phase difference between the rays coming from the edges of the slit is
explanation_plain_text:
Path difference between the wavelets from the top edge and the bottom edge of the slit is where is the slit width.

Phase difference

explanation_txt:
\(Bev=\cfrac{\mathrm{m} v^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}\)
or, \(r = \cfrac{\mathrm{mv}}{\mathrm{Be}}=\cfrac{\sqrt{2 \mathrm{mE}}}{\mathrm{Be}}\)
\(\quad=\cfrac{\sqrt{2 \times 9.1 \times 10^{-31} \times 500 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}}{20 \times 10^{-3} \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}\)
\(\quad=3.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}\)

quest_title: Force of attraction between two point charges \(Q\) and \(- Q\) separated by \(d\) metre is \(F _ { e } .\) When these charges are placed on two identical spheres of radius \(R = 0.3 d\) whose centres are \(d\) metre apart, the force of attraction between them is
explanation_txt: Separation between the spheres is not too large as compared to their radius so due to induction effect redistribution of charge takes place. Hence, effective charge separation decreases and the force of attraction increases.

quest_title: If a 2 \(\mu\)F condenser is charged to 200 volts and its plates are connected by a wire, the heat produced in the wire is
explanation_txt:
Heat produced in wire \(=\) energy stored in capacitor

Heat produced in wire \(=\cfrac{1}{2} C V^{2}\)

Heat produced in wire \(=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 10^{-6} \times(200)^{2}\)

Heat produced in wire \(=200 \times 200 \times 10^{-6}\)

Heat produced in wire \(=4 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{J}\)

quest_title: The magnetic induction at the centre \(\textit{O}\) in the figure shown is
explanation_txt:
In the following figure, magnetic fields at \(\textit{O}\) due to sections 1, 2, 3 and 4 are considered as \(B_{1} ,\, B_{2} ,\, B_{3} \) and \(B_{4} \) respectively.

\[B_{1} =B_{3} =0\] \[B_{2} =\cfrac{\mu _{0} }{4\pi } .\cfrac{\pi \, i}{R_{1} }\]

\(B_{4} =\cfrac{\mu _{0} }{4\pi }. \cfrac{\pi \, i}{R_{2} } \) As \(|B_{2} |\, \, >\, \, |B_{4} |\)

So \(B_{net} =B_{2} -B_{4} \Rightarrow B_{net} =\cfrac{\mu _{0} i}{4} \left(\cfrac{1}{R_{1} } -\cfrac{1}{R_{2} } \right)\)

quest_title: An aeroplane in which the distance between the tips of wings is 50 meter is flying horizontally with a speed of 360 km/hr over a place where the vertical component of earth's magnetic field is 2.0 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) Tesla. The potential difference between the tips of wings would be
explanation_txt:
\(E=V B l=\left(360 \times \cfrac{5}{18}\right) \times\left(2 \times 10^{-4}\right) \times 50 \)
\(E=V B l=1.0 \text { volt } \)

quest_title: Which of the following is not correct for resonance?
ans2_txt: The same energy of contributing structures
ans3_txt: The same number of paired electrons
ans4_txt: Not the same arrangement of atoms.
explanation_txt:
Options 'a' to 'c' are the requirements for resonating structures.

Resonance structures are a set of two or more Lewis Structures that collectively describe the electronic bonding a single polyatomic species including fractional bonds and fractional charges. The arrangement of atoms is same, but the bonding is different.
question_plain_title: Which of the following is not correct for resonance?
explanation_plain_text:
Options 'a' to 'c' are the requirements for resonating structures.

Resonance structures are a set of two or more Lewis Structures that collectively describe the electronic bonding a single polyatomic species including fractional bonds and fractional charges. The arrangement of atoms is same, but the bonding is different.
ans2_plain_text: The same energy of contributing structures
ans3_plain_text: The same number of paired electrons
ans4_plain_text: Not the same arrangement of atoms.

NOTE: \( 1 - \cfrac{1}{2} + \cfrac{1}{3} - \cfrac{1}{4} + \cfrac{1}{5} - \cfrac{1}{6} + \dots \log {2} \)

quest_title: In hydrogen spectrum, the shortest wavelength of Balmer series is \(\lambda\)\({}_{o}\) then shortest wavelength of Brackett series will be
explanation_txt:
For Balmer series
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda_{\mathrm{a}}}=\mathrm{R}\left[\cfrac{1}{4}\right]\)
Or, \(\lambda_{\mathrm{a}}=\cfrac{4}{\mathrm{R}} \ldots \ldots \ldots (1)\)

For Brackett series
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda}=\mathrm{R}\left[\cfrac{1}{16}\right]\)
\(\lambda=\cfrac{16}{\mathrm{R}} \quad \ldots \ldots \ldots (2)\)

Dividing ( 2 ) by (1)
\(\cfrac{\lambda}{\lambda_{a}}=4\)
\(\therefore \lambda=4 \lambda_{a}\)
question_plain_title: In hydrogen spectrum, the shortest wavelength of Balmer series is then shortest wavelength of Brackett series will be
explanation_plain_text:
For Balmer series

Or,

For Brackett series

Dividing ( 2 ) by (1)
ans1_plain_text: 2
ans2_plain_text: 4
ans3_plain_text: 9
ans4_plain_text: 16

quest_title: Galvanization is the process of applying protective coating of _____ on _____
explanation_txt: Iron has a great affinity to react with oxygen in the presence of moisture and rust. Zn is used as sacrificial metal and applied over iron to prevent its rusting. This is called 'Galvanization'.
